violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy
Section (1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall at a
Description minimum, include all of the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The foster child cannot walk or talk and is limited to using a
wheelchair. The child has not had a wheelchair that fits since July
2022 due to outgrowing it and the agency has refused to provide
another one until her insurance provides such in March 2023.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent B
On 12/20/2023 I interviewed Parent B/complainant by telephone.
Parent B confirmed the information in the complaint. She reported
Child A is eight years old and has been in care with Ennis-Howell
since 6/8/2022. She reported the agency had opportunity to obtain
the wheelchair in November 2022, when she and the caregiver
went to order the equipment. Ennis refused to get the wheelchair,
reported they do not have the money, and Child A would have to
get the new wheelchair when the insurance provider can pay for it,
which is not until March 2023.
Program Director (PD) 2
2

On 1/11/2023 I interviewed Program Director 2 onsite. PD 2
reported reviewing the case record upon receipt of this complaint.
He reported when Child A was placed with the agency on
6/8/2022, she came with a wheelchair. He said there were no
concerns known about the wheelchair until after Child A was
placed with Caregiver 4. He said the issue of Child A’s wheelchair
being too small did not come to the attention of the assigned
worker, Foster Care Worker (FCW), until 10/25/2022. PD 2
reported knowing this because of an email FCW 4 sent the POS
(Purchase of Service) Department of Health and Human Services
(DHHS) Worker asking for assistance, due to Child A getting too
big for her wheelchair. The DHHS Worker referred FCW 4 to
Child A’s insurance provider. He said it was going to take three
months to get a new wheelchair via Child A’s insurance.
PD 2 said Parent B told the worker Child A’s wheelchair had come
from the school Child A attended while in Parent B’s care.
Additionally, that the school would give updated wheelchairs.
Ennis contacted the school and the school reported they provide
or would help with getting an updated wheelchair to a child who
has outgrown a wheelchair or has a damaged wheelchair. PD 2
reported the agency did not seek assistance via the school
because they were advised Child A would have to be enrolled with
the school and Child A had not been enrolled there since 2018.
PD 2 said Caregiver D intervened after FCW 4 had checked with
the insurance company. Caregiver D ordered a wheelchair on her
own on 11/30/2022. A wheelchair came but it was not appropriate
as it did not have the harness scraps required to secure Child A
in, so the wheelchair had to be sent back. PD 2 reported the
order was wrong and it was Caregiver D’s error. He did not know
how Caregiver 2 knew how to go about ordering a specialized
wheelchair or how she got the wrong kind of wheelchair. He said
it was just Caregiver D trying to get something sooner for Child A.
He reported a reordered wheelchair would not come until
sometime in March 2023. It would take three months to make the
wheelchair. He reported as of 1/4/2023 the agency, per a doctor’s
suggestions began exploring renting a wheelchair for Child A. He
denied the caregiver ever complaining about Child A being without
an appropriate wheelchair.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3
On 1/11/2023 I interviewed FCW 3 onsite. FCW 3 reported being
assigned to Child A’s case on 10/24/2022. She reported being
unaware of an issue with Child A’s wheelchair until after the
receipt of this complaint. Prior to this complaint Parent B, nor
3

Caregiver D had complained or reported a concern about Child
A’s wheelchair being too small.
FCW 3 reported prior to this complaint, she had an initial visit with
the child and Caregiver D on 11/14/2022. She had transported
Child A from a grandparents’ visit to Caregiver D’s. She had put
Child A’s wheelchair in her truck but did not notice an issue with it.
She did not see Child A in the wheelchair at that time. She
reported at some point Caregiver D informed her they had ordered
a wheelchair, but when it arrived, it was the incorrect one and it
did not have the straps and could not be buckled into the bus for
transport. FCW 3 did not know from where Caregiver D obtained
the wheelchair. Caregiver D had ordered the wheelchair, but not
by going through the proper channels. After an incorrect
wheelchair came in, the family used the proper medical channel,
via Dr X and Sparrow medical equipment for the reorder. FCW 3
reported Caregiver D informed her there was an appointment at
“Sparrows” a medical equipment place in Lansing on 11/30/2022.
Caregiver D did not report the current wheelchair was preventing
her from transporting Child A.
FCW 3 reported on 1/3/2023 she made a home visit, observed
Child A in the wheelchair, but could not tell if the wheelchair was
too small. Nor was she able to discern whether Child A was
uncomfortable in the wheelchair. She acknowledged it did look as
if the wheelchair could be bigger. She said Caregiver D reported
Child A’s current wheelchair is a 10-inch size, and the new one
that was ordered was a 12 or 14 inch one. She affirmed PD 2’s
reporting related to March 2023 expected date for the new
wheelchair. FCW 3 said, “I didn’t feel it was a real disadvantage
for the new wheelchair to not come until March 2023 because I
didn’t see it was a problem” and Caregiver D was working on
getting the wheelchair.
FCW 3 reported the agency was attempting to obtain another
wheelchair for Child A sooner, by renting one. She said on
1/4/2023 she contacted the Sparrow medical facility about renting
one. She was advised to speak with their warehouse and at the
time of this interview, she was awaiting a reply.
Caregiver C
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver C by telephone. Caregiver
C reported Child A’s placement with her as 6/6/2022 until
10/3/2022. She said DHHS placed Child A with her and
transferred Child A’s case to Ennis.
4

Caregiver C reported prior to Child A starting school in September
2022, there was not an issue with Child A’s wheelchair. She said
during the summer Child A gained a lot of weight. While at school
they noticed bruising on the area between Child A’s thighs and
near the bone area where the wheelchair strap fits. Caregiver C
said she reported the wheelchair issue to FCW 4 around
9/20/2022. FCW 4 told her FCW 4 would work on getting Child A
a new wheelchair, but then FCW 4 resigned from Ennis and Child
A was replaced to Caregiver C aunt’s, Caregiver D. Caregiver C
reported Child A does not currently have a functional wheelchair.
Caregiver D
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver D by telephone. Caregiver
D reported Child A was placed with her on 10/3/2022, but Child A
is returning to Child A’s mother’s care today.
Caregiver D reported for the first month of Child A’s placement
with her, FCW 4 was the worker. Caregiver D reported letting the
agency know there was as issue with Child A’s wheelchair “almost
from the beginning” of Child A’s placement with her. She said the
agency knew already, because Child A's prior placement,
Caregiver C had told them the wheelchair was too small. She
reported just before she put in her 30-day request to have Child A
replaced from her home on 1/6/2023, the agency told her they
were trying to rent Child A a wheelchair. Caregiver D never heard
back from the worker on the rental issue/status.
Caregiver D acknowledged trying to obtain a new wheelchair for
Child A. She did that by calling the Carelink insurance and having
the doctor Child A was seeing to write a prescription for the
wheelchair. She said when the wheelchair came it was a regular
old wheelchair. She affirmed PD 2’s and FCW 3’s reporting about
it not having the necessary straps for bus lock in/for safety
securement. She said Medicaid paid for the wheelchair, but since
it was returned there was no charge incurred. Thereafter, they
went to an equipment place for measurements for Child A. That
occurred on 11/30/2022, at which time she was told it would take
three months to build it. Caregiver D reported telling all this to the
agency and she was advised to just wait.
Caregiver D reported there was only an issue getting Child A
around when they needed to take her places. She said the
agency assisted with transportation, but Child A was just too wide
and had outgrown the wheelchair.
Document Review:
5

On 1/11/2023, I examined Child A’s case record and/or I was
provided the document. I reviewed:
• MISACWIS which showed:
➢ Child A was placement with Ennis-Howell on
6/8/2022.
➢ She was placed with Caregiver C, an aunt, from
6/8/2022 to 10/4/2022.
➢ She was placed with Caregiver D, another
aunt/relative on 10/4/2022.
➢ A medical for Child A dated 6/24/2022 that indicated
Child A is diagnosed with Jacobson’s Syndrome; is
non-verbal; does not walk; has severe Autism delay;
has heart issues; and had surgery for a congenital
heart defect seven days ago.
➢ A copy of a 10/25/2022 email from FCW 4 to Child
A’s DHHS-POS worker. The email indicated Child A
is “very close to being too big for her wheelchair.
Are there any resources you are aware of that I can
utilize to assist the family in obtaining one? The
DHHS-POS worker referred FCW 4 to the child’s
insurance company.
• No documentation of a report by Caregiver C related to a
wheelchair need, but a 10/28/2022 agency home visit sheet
that indicated Child A needs a new wheelchair.
• A photo of Child A sitting in a wheelchair, in which Child A
appears to completely fill in the seat with no apparent extra
room.
Analysis Based on interviews, the agency did not timely and effectively
follow up on Child A’s need for a larger wheelchair. The delay, and
lack of direct communication with the child’s second caregiver
around the wheelchair and what would be needed to secure a
proper wheelchair, contributed to a wheelchair not being secured
timely.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12409 Education Policy.
Section (1) An agency’s education policy shall ensure that, within 5 school
Description days of placement, an agency shall provide for the enrollment of
each child of school age, as defined by state law, into a school
program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The foster child had only attended school one day out of the
school year.
6

Investigation Interviews:
Parent B
On 12/20/2023 I interviewed Parent B/Complainant by telephone.
Parent B reported Child A is not in school and has not been in
school since she was placed with Caregiver D in October 2022.
Additionally, that when Child A was placed with Parent B’s sister,
Caregiver C, Caregiver C only sent Child A to school one day.
Parent B said, Child A used to attend Beekman Center in Lansing.
The agency promised when Child A moved to Caregiver D, who
lives two hours away from Lansing, they would get Child A placed
in a special education school. The agency has not secured a
school for Child A, nor services that they promised her.
Program Director (PD) 2
On 1/11/2023 I interviewed Program Director 2 onsite. PD 2
reported it is true that Child A is not enrolled in school and has
basically not been attending school since being in Ennis’s care.
He said FCW 4 was working on getting Child A in school. In mid-
August thru 9/29/2022 FCW 4 sought to obtain Child A’s
attendance records from Beekman, the school Child A had
attended in Lansing, while in her mother’s care. The agency did
not discover until sometime later, that school had no records and
that Child A had only attended that school for one day, contrary to
what Parent B had reported. PD did not report what other types of
follow up the agency attempted to get Child A in school/to work
through whatever barriers existed.
PD 2 reported Child A missed school while placed with Caregiver
C, due to COVID and other issues. He reported when Child A
was placed with Caregiver D, FCW 4 spoke with someone in the
school district in September or October about getting Child A
enrolled. That person did not contact FCW 4 back for 21 days and
by that time FCW 4 was leaving the agency. He said FCW 3
picked up the case on 10/24/2022, and FCW 3 contacted the
Foster Care Liaison Representative (FCLR) for assistance on
11/17/2022. The FCLR referred FCW 3 to the Greenville
Intermediate School District (ISD). He said there was a gap in
contact thereafter and FCW 3 followed up with the ISD on
1/4/2023, but Child A remains out of school.
Foster Care Worker 3
On 1/11/2023 I interviewed FCW 3 onsite. FCW 3 reported when
she took over Child A’s case on 10/24/2022, Child A was not in
school. Nor was Child A in school at the time of this interview.
7

FCW 3 was not sure what school Child A would now be attending
because Caregiver D has requested Child A’s replacement.
FCW 3 reported FCW 4 had informed her that FCW 4 was
attempting to register Child A in Vestaburg schools. FCW 4 was
trying to obtain a release of information in order to get Child A
records. FCW 3 said she did not know until after the fact that a
Vestaburg school representative had contacted FCW 4, so, she
did not know to do anything else. She did not follow up on school
until 11/14/2022. She contacted the FCLR as reported by PM 2.
She was advised the school district would do the necessary
testing, paper work, and would transfer Child A to the ISD. FCW 3
reported after that, she contacted Vestaburg schools and spoke
with the Special Education Coordinator (SEC) who recalled Child
A's case as reported by FCW 4. The SEC affirmed the information
reported by the FCLR, though nothing was reported related to a
release of information. Follow up and appointment scheduling
was pending for Child A. FCW 3 said she followed up on the
matter once in December 2022, and the SEC was not available for
about a month after that. FCW 3 said she finally spoke with the
SEC on 1/4/2023. The SEC scheduled an intake school
registration meeting for 1/12/2023 at 1:00PM. At that time Child
A, Caregiver D, and Parent B would meet with someone from the
ISD along with the school psychologist and a teacher’s consultant.
FCW 3 said the 1/12/2023 appointment now has to be
rescheduled. Parent B has a conflicting appointment, and Parent
B reports she cannot reschedule her appointment. A new
appointment cannot go forward because Parent B has to be there
to sign the paperwork. FCW 3 said she gave Parent B the TEC’s
telephone number. FCW 3 reported, she is trying to get Parent
B’s consent on this matter, but Parent B’s cooperation has always
been a struggle. Parent B believes Child A is coming back home
to her, and this may be why Parent B does not cooperate.
Additionally, information Parent B reports is many times not
correct, and also not truthful. Parent B said Child A’s school
records were at Harwood, where Parent B obtained Child A’s
wheelchair, and the school provides updated wheelchairs every
five years. All of this was revealed to be untrue. Hardwood
reported Child A was enrolled in their school in January 2018 and
disenrolled in February 2018. The school reported never seeing
Child A or Parent B.
Caregiver C
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver C by telephone. Caregiver
C said Child A was not in school when Child A was first placed
with her because it was summer. She said Child A was not
8

enrolled in school until the middle of September 2022, because
the worker was delinquent in getting her the permission form to
enroll Child A. She also had to get the IEP (Individualized
Education Plan) from the Hardwood school, and she had to obtain
Child A’s birth certificate from Parent B. Caregiver C said Child A
only attended school for a week, because soon after Child A
started, Child A’s placement change occurred.
Caregiver C reported Child A has not been in school during all the
time Child A had been placed with Caregiver D. She said that is
because there are no schools in the area Caregiver D resides.
Caregiver D
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver D by telephone. Caregiver
D reported residing in Montcalm County, in Vestaburg Michigan.
She confirmed that Child A had not attended school since
placement with her, on 10/3/2022. She acknowledged monthly
home visits by the agency workers but could not recall the specific
discussions related to school. She reported for the first month of
Child A’s placement with her, FCW 4 was the worker. She said
both FCW 3 and FCW 4 kept telling her they were trying to get
Child A placed in school. They reported they were contacting the
Vestaburg school district, and no one was calling them back.
Neither worker asked her to go up to the school. She said she
would have gone, but she was under the impression the agency
staff were to do that. She reported earlier this month, FCW 3
reported obtaining an appointment with the Vestaburg school
district and a meeting was set for 1/10/2023 or 1/12/2023 to
discuss Child A's school placement. That meeting has since been
cancelled because of her 30-day request to have Child A replaced
from her home, and Parent B was not being okay with signing the
needed school paperwork for the meeting.
Document Review:
On 12/20/2022 I reviewed Child A’s MISAWIS record. On
1/11/2023, I examined Child A’s physical case record, or I was
provided the document. I reviewed:
• The information as previously reported.
• A Team Decision Meeting (TDM) on 10/3/22 that indicated
Child A is enrolled at the Beekman Center school. She will
be enrolled at a special education school in the St. Louis
area which is closer to her new placement.
• Child A’s Initial Service Plan (ISP) for 6/8/2022-7/7/2022,
which documented a 6/17/2022 home visit with Caregiver C
indicating Caregiver C is working on getting Child A
9

enrolled in Harwood elementary in Mason, Michigan where
Child A had previously attended for a couple of days.
• A 7/5/2022 Family Team Meeting (FTM) that indicated the
worker will work with the family to decide which school will
be best for Child A and getting her enrolled.
• Child A’s Updated Service Plan (USP) for 7/8/2022-
10/5/2022 which indicated via a 9/6/2022 caregiver visit
contact, that Child A will be attending the Beekman school
Center. Child A will go a couple of days per week and will
transition to five days a week. The school will provide
therapy to Child A during school hours. Additionally, a
9/9/2022 social work contact indicating Parent B
accompanied Child A and Caregiver C to complete Child
A’s school enrollment. Child A will begin on 9/13/2022.
• A copy of a 10/10/2022 email to FCW 4 from the Lansing
school district, and FCW 4’s confirmation response. The
email asked for confirmation of what Caregiver C reported
to the school about Child A being placed with another
family outside the Lansing School District. The school
wanted confirmation of that so that Child A could be
unenrolled with the district.
• An MISACWIS upload of a 11/29/2017 Ingham County
School District Individualized Educational Program Team
Report.
• A MISACWIS school profile document upload for Beekman
Center for Child A’s school enrollment on 8/29/2022 while
with Caregiver C. No school enrollment document related
to placement with Caregiver D.
• Copies of Ennis home visit sheets for:
➢ 6/17/2022 that indicated Child A has not been
attending school.
➢ 10/28/2022 that indicated Child A is not in school
yet. Need to contact St. Louis Schools.
➢ 11/14/2022 that indicated look into Greenville
Schools. No other details were listed.
➢ 12/9/2022 that indicated Child A is not in school yet.
No plan of action was indicated.
• Copies of emails back and forth from 1/9/2023 to 1/11/2023
between FPD 2, FCW3, Parent B and the SEC related to
getting Child A registered for school.
➢ The SEC ended the matter by advising PD 2 that
notwithstanding his reference to the law, no one has
filled out the registration paperwork. That the
process to have Child A registered is to obtain the
IEP and evaluation/medical records, and then the
team determines placement. That with the extensive
10

needs Child A may have this process is especially
important. The SEC advised meeting as planned on
1/12/2022 and having the team to join once the SEC
has more information.
➢ FCW 3 advised the SEC that since the agency had
not received a registration form prior, the plan was to
complete it at the appointment on 1/12/2023.
Analysis The evidence showed the agency did not enroll Child A in school
after she was placed with Caregiver D as required by the rule. Nor
did the agency follow up timely on issues related to securing a
specialized educational program for Child A. The agency did not
make diligent efforts until after the receipt of this complaint.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency has not provided the foster child with promised
Autism services or physical therapy.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent B
On 12/20/2023 I interviewed Parent B/complainant by telephone.
Parent B reported the agency is reporting there are no physical
therapy providers in the area that Caregiver D resides. The
agency just makes excuses as to why they have not obtained the
services. The agency also reported they would get Child A in
home services for Autism, but they have not done so. The agency
reports they are waiting on a referral or waiting on a call.
Parent B reported not believing the agency’s reporting. She stated
Child A has not received physical therapy since the summer of
2022, nor the services Child A needs.
Program Director (PD) 2
On 1/11/2023 I interviewed Program Director 2 onsite. PD 2
reported it was true Child A is diagnosed with Autism. He said
Parent B reported that Child A had received physical therapy
11

service related to this disorder in the past. He reported that would
be assessed via a CMH (Community Mental Health) screening
with Parent B’s participation, but Parent B can be difficult, and that
at times Parent B has not signed all required releases. PD 2
believes Child A may have been receiving physical and
occupational therapy, via Sparrow, while in the care of Caregiver
C. With respect to these services while Child A was with Caregiver
D, PD 2 reported the agency asked Caregiver D to complete the
screening so that a service intake could occur, but that did not
occur.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3
On 1/11/2023 I interviewed FCW 3 onsite. FCW 3 said Child A
was receiving physical and occupational services while placed
with Caregiver C. Child A received the services via the Sparrow
Health System, but Child A only attended nine sessions between
June 2022 and October 2022. FCW 3 said she called to get
information about the services for the case service plan, but
Parent B would not sign the release of information.
FCW 3 said when Child A was replaced to Caregiver D’s home,
she did not know she needed a referral for these services to
continue. She did not do anything about it, and she was not sure
whether Caregiver D knew if another referral was needed. FCW 3
reported she completed a new referral on 1/4/2023 via Montcalm
Care network related to these services. An appointment was set
for 1/10/2023. The appointment was cancelled by the service
provider because Parent B would only sign the consent to treat,
but not the consent to bill Medicaid. FCW 3 reported now that
Child A will be leaving Caregiver D’s home, the agency will work
on these services again at a later date, as opposed to fighting with
Parent B now.
FCW 3 reported reviewing Child A’s file related to assessing
whether other service referral existed and were followed up on for
Child A’s. She saw an order for ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat),
pediatric gastro, and neurologist. She contacted Dr X’s office and
spoke with someone a number of times. On 1/3/2023 she spoke
with someone at Dr X’s office about the referrals made in June
2022. The doctor’s office reported not knowing whether Caregiver
C had followed up on those orders, or whether the service
providers did not contact Caregiver C. FCW 3 said, Dr. X
reissued the referrals. She said Parent B, with the exception of
consenting for an annual cardiologist (Parent B said the last one
was in 2018) examination, is refusing to consent to the other
appointments. Parent B reported on 1/3/2023 and 1/5/2023 that
12

Child A needs to see a genetics doctor via the University of
Michigan and needs an appointment to see an optometrist. FCW 3
said Dr X sent out the order for the latter two service requests on
1/5/2023.
Caregiver C
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver C by telephone. Caregiver
C reported Child A was receiving occupational and physical
therapy via the Sparrow Health System in Lansing, during Child
A’s placement time with her. She transported Child A for these
services one to three time weekly. Child A attended for at least
three months or more prior to Child A starting school in September
2022.
Caregiver C reported it was true that Child A was in need of
services related to Child A’s Autism. She said that is why Child A
was receiving occupational and physical therapy. Child A was also
receiving speech therapy. All were occurring about once per
week. The services had been recommended via an evaluation by
Sparrow Health System. Caregiver C reported once school
started Child A was to receive those services via the school
system not Sparrow. She said the school held a Multiple
Disciplinary Team meeting related to all the services Child A
needed. The school was going to provide the services, but then
Child A was replaced from her home. She said the only
documentation Sparrow provider her was a list of service dates,
which she provided to FCW 4.
Caregiver D
On 1/27/2023 I interviewed Caregiver D by telephone. Caregiver
D reported the agency reported they were trying to get Child A
these services via the school district.
Document Review

Allegation During the investigation it was alleged an agency staff was
carrying Child A during transports. It was reported a staff person
was trying to have Child A, who cannot walk, to walk on the cold
ground without shoes.
Investigation Interviews:
On 1/17/2023 Chief Administrator 1 contacted me by email about
this issue. She reported Child A’s maternal grandparents sent a
video to PD 2 about the issue on 1/13/2023. Chief Administrator
1’s email to me indicated:
• The video showed Ennis’ case aide struggling to carry
Child A from the car to the front door of Child A’s
grandparent’s home where she was visiting for respite.
• The video showed Child A wore socks and did not have
shoes or thicker socks to protect and keep her feet warm.
• The video showed during the struggle Child A’s feet
touched the ground as the case aide was re-adjusting her
grip.
• The agency understands there is a training need for the
staff to learn how to transport a disabled youth safely and
properly, and to ensure the youth are always dressed
appropriately for the weather.
• When the agency questioned the case aide why Child A’s
wheelchair was not used, the staff expressed concerns with
the mother citing the wheelchair was too small and caused
discomfort to Child A.
• The agency is looking to provide Child A with a new wheel
chair because she has yet to receive the chair that was
previously ordered for her.
• In regard to training staff, they have advised staff to not
carry Child A during transporting and to ensure Child A is
always appropriately dressed in appropriate footwear in the
form of shoes/boots or thick socks to ensure her feet are
warm.
• The agency is also seeking training from medical
professionals to conduct an agency training on proper use
of a wheelchair.
Chief Administrator 1 provided me copy of a video sent to PD 2 by
Child A’s grandparents.
Caregiver C
During my telephone interview with Caregiver C on 1/27/2023,
Caregiver C reported Child A does not currently have a functional
wheelchair. She said agency staff are carrying Child A around.
She said during one incident a couple of weeks ago she had to
assist the transporter in strapping Child A in the car seat. In
17

another incident the transport worker was trying to have Child
walk. She said Child A cannot really walk, but Child A is trying to
walk. She reported it was cold out and Child A’s feet were on the
ground and the child did not have shoes on. Caregiver C was not
sure who those workers were but reported there is a video.
Caregiver D
During my telephone interview with Caregiver D on 1/27/2023, she
reported knowledge of a worker, not the FCW, carrying Child A
out the car and almost dropping her. Caregiver D saw the video,
not the actual incident. She said the worker was holding Child A’s
hand to let Child A walk. She affirmed what Caregiver C reported
related to Child A being able to take a few steps and her not
having shoes on during the incident.
Case Aide 5
On 2/28/ 2023, Interviewed Case Aide 5 by telephone. Case Aide
5 reported after she took Child A out of the car seat and the car,
Case Aide 5’s arms failed her. Child A was in her arms, but she
could not pick Child A up. She tried again to pick Child A up, but
her arms failed her again. She tried to lean Child A up against the
car, but she could not get Child A positioned correctly. While still
holding on to Child A, she momentarily placed Child A on the
ground in a standing position. Child A took a couple of steps and
while Child A was standing on the ground, Case Aide 5 was able
to grip Child A from behind/from under Child A’s arms and lift her
up to carry her. Case Aide 5 reported Child A’s grandfather came
out as Child A took the couple of steps. The grandfather did not
offer her any assistance. The grandfather asked what was going
on and commented on Child A feet being on the ground, possibly
getting cold. Case Aide 5 said she apologized to the grandfather
for letting Child A down with just her socks on.
Case Aide 5 reported she did not transport Child A with a
wheelchair. She was told by FCW 3 the wheelchair was to
small/did not fit Child A, so she assumed the chair was not safe.
Additionally, Case Aide 5 acknowledged that it was not
appropriate that Child A was only in her socks. She said in the
past Child A has had shoes on. She reported when she picked
Child A up from Caregiver D’s home for the transport to the
grandparents, Caregiver D said Child A had kicked off her shoes.
Case Aide 5 assumed the shoes were in Child A’s bag, that
Caregiver D had placed them there, but she did not check. When
she arrived at the grandparents’ home, she looked in the bag for
the shoes and discovered the caregiver had not sent them. She
said she did not have the grandparent contact information to call
18

them for assistance. She reported not getting a chance to call the
agency for the information because of things transpiring as they
had. She reported after this incident she knows the grandparents
and Parent B were upset with FCW 4 about the incident. Case
Aide 5 said her supervisor spoke with her about the incident. Her
supervisor advised her to make sure the child always has her
shoes.
Video Review:
I reviewed the video that was provided by Chief Administrator 1 on
1/17/2023. The video showed:
• Actions similar to what was reported by Chief Administrator
1 in her email.
• Child A was in socks, there were remnants of snow on the
ground.
• The case aide held Child A from the back, and she
momentarily placed Child A on the ground in a standing
position. Child A made a couple of steps as the case aide
held her from the back, after which time the case aide was
able to get a grip and pick Child A up.
• A male voice asking the case aide what was going on;
and thereafter stating Child A does not have shoes on;
Child A feet must be cold.
• The case aide replied to the male voice that she was just
walking Child A a little bit.
Analysis The evidence is insufficient to support intentional or purposeful
negligence toward Child A, or a lack of effort to work with the child
and the child’s family, and relevant individuals related to the case
service plan. The case aide briefly placed the child down while
she still had the child around the waist so that she could gain a
better and firmer grip to pick the child up and carry her into the
house.
Technical Assistance:
It is recommended that the agency follow through with the training
plan Chief Administrator 1 reported pertaining to safe transporting
of disabled children, the proper use of wheelchairs and staff
ensuring children are dressed appropriate for a transport. Proof of
training shall be documented for the staff.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
